title: Chapter 8 – Group Life (GLA) Features & Tax (Original MCQs)

questions.stem: A GLA scheme pays 3× pensionable salary on death in service. Pensionable salary is 90% of basic salary. If basic salary is £60,000, what is the lump-sum benefit?
Which statement about discretionary trusts in GLA is MOST accurate?
options: They make the employee’s nomination legally binding.
They typically allow faster payment and potential inheritance‑tax advantages.
They remove the need for any claims assessment.
They require all beneficiaries to be named in the policy schedule.
questions.explanation: Discretionary trusts allow trustees to decide recipients, often speeding payment and improving tax efficiency. Nominations are guidance, not binding.

questions.stem: Which factor is LEAST likely to affect the GLA unit rate for a scheme?
options: Age distribution of members
Industry/occupation mix
The insurer’s claims handling SLA wording
Historic claims experience (for large schemes)
questions.explanation: Pricing depends on risk factors (age, occupation) and experience. SLA wording on claims service has minimal direct impact on pure risk cost.

questions.stem: A member’s basic salary is £48,500 and pensionable salary is £45,000. The scheme pays 4× basic salary. What is the benefit?
Which BEST explains the purpose of a Free Cover Limit (FCL) in GLA?
options: It caps the total scheme benefit payable in a catastrophe.
It sets a per‑member threshold below which no individual medical evidence is required.
It removes the need for actively‑at‑work clauses.
It guarantees acceptance above the threshold with a loading.
questions.explanation: FCL simplifies onboarding by allowing cover up to a limit without individual underwriting; above it, evidence may be required.

questions.stem: Who usually decides the distribution of GLA lump‑sum benefits on a member’s death?
options: The nominated beneficiary, automatically
The insurer’s underwriter
The trustees/plan administrators under discretion
The member’s line manager
questions.explanation: Trustees/administrators exercise discretion, taking the nomination as guidance.

questions.stem: Which payroll change is MOST likely to increase the scheme’s total premium for a multiple‑of‑salary GLA benefit?
options: Moving the definition from basic salary to pensionable salary where pensionable is lower
Adding a higher paid grade with significantly higher basic salaries
Reducing the benefit multiple from 4× to 3×
No change to salaries but improving the insurer’s SLA
questions.explanation: Higher salaries increase sum assured directly under multiple‑of‑salary designs.

questions.stem: Which communication is MOST important for employees in a GLA scheme?
options: How to request a reinsurer facultative placement
How to complete/update nomination forms and what a discretionary trust means
How to price catastrophe reinsurance
How to switch from unit‑rated to experience‑rated terms
questions.explanation: Clear nomination guidance and trust explanation are key for dependants’ outcomes.

questions.stem: For a small employer new to GLA with no claims history, which pricing basis is MOST likely?
options: Experience‑rated
Unit‑rated (pooled)
Manual rate plus experience load
Self‑insured
questions.explanation: Small schemes typically use pooled unit rates as they lack credible experience.

questions.stem: Why might a large corporate negotiate a higher FCL with the insurer?
options: To avoid any need for eligibility checks
To reduce the number of members requiring medical evidence
To guarantee lower unit rates
To make nominations legally binding
questions.explanation: Higher FCLs reduce the frequency of individual underwriting while maintaining scheme controls.

questions.stem: Which BEST describes the typical tax treatment (principle-level) of employer GLA premiums for employees?
options: Taxable benefit in kind for employees
Not a taxable benefit in kind for employees (subject to current HMRC rules)
Always taxed through payroll
Taxed only if benefit multiple exceeds 4×
questions.explanation: Generally not a BI K for employees; employers usually treat premiums as a business expense (check current HMRC rules each year).

questions.stem: Which factor is MOST likely to drive the need for facultative reinsurance on a GLA case?
options: A very high single‑member sum assured
Improved data quality
Lower occupation risk
Shorter rate guarantee period
questions.explanation: Very large individual sums often exceed treaty limits and require facultative approval.
